A project manager is facilitating a project steering committee meeting where the prioritization of work items in the backlog is being discussed. The engineering executive wants to prioritize features based on level of effort, completing the smallest items first. The quality executive wants to complete the most complex tasks first to have adequate time to ensure a quality product is delivered. The compliance officer wants to complete items with associated regulatory components as they are essential items.

How should the project manager prioritize the work items?

choices.D: Complete the smaller tasks first to allow the team opportunities to prototype and evaluate development processes.
choices.A: Ensure that the project value is within the quality guidelines by prioritizing and completing intricate tasks earlier in the project.
choices.C: Ensure that the team assesses opportunities to deliver the highest business value items incrementally.
choices.B: Complete tasks associated with regulatory components as the team cannot deliver business value that does not adhere to compliance regulations.

D. Plan for continuous validation of the product.

Planning for continuous validation helps ensure that quality is built into the product development process from the start. It allows for ongoing assessment and verification at every stage, reducing the risk of major issues being discovered after delivery. This approach aligns with agile practices and ensures that issues are detected early and addressed promptly, preventing delays in future feature development.

Proactive vs. Reactive Approach
Option C: Adding more test scenarios based on the issues found is a reactive measure. It focuses on addressing the specific problems identified after they have already caused rework and delays. This approach might solve the current issues but doesn't necessarily prevent future problems.
Option D: Continuous validation is a proactive approach. It involves regularly checking and validating the product throughout its development. This helps to identify and address potential issues early and continuously, preventing significant problems from accumulating and causing delays.
